content: quote: NEW YORK (CBS) ― Anxiety has turned into frustration, and that frustration has boiled over at City Hall where tens of thousands of people took to the streets to vent to city and state officials. Organizers estimate that 50,000 people have lined Broadway with a message to Gov. David Paterson that cuts are not the answer to fixing New York's budget problems. The protesters are made up of a widespread coalition of labor unions, community groups, and even families uniting to have their voices heard. Dubbing it a "Rally for New York," they are rallying against proposed state and city budget cuts to public services, education, health care, along with other programs that impact families and the economy in New York. "I have not lost the feeling for good education. You can't cut the budget the way it is and still have the quality we're aiming for there's no question about that. So we're fighting for the children first, and then the teachers and the workers after that, and for the city of course," said George Altomare, a retired teacher who was protesting told CBS 2. CBS 2's Hazel Sanchez says the group is calling for fair share tax reform, and increasing the income tax of new Yorkers earning $250,000 or more, generating $6 billion and they hope to prevent the cuts. <more> "http://wcbstv.com/breakingnewsalerts/recession.budget.protest.2.951551.html Sheesh ... if I was making more than $250K, I'd be feeling too much love. POTUS 44 wants my money ... New Yorkers want my money ... yea ... that's "fair share" tax reform.

If your income range is between $8,001 and $11,000, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 4.5%. If your income range is between $11,001 and $13,000, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 5.25%. If your income range is between $13,001 and $20,000, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 5.9%. If your income range is between $100,001 and $500,000, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 7.375%. If your income range is $500,001 and over, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 7.7%. Notice how the wealthy pay sooooooo much greater a percentage than I do? Almost (but not quite) two entire percentage points... I must be Very Wealthy! Dave

Now ... these stories came up back when POTUS 44 first set his federal tax boundary at $250K so I imagine they aren't too happy to hear NY might deliver them a double whammy. I ask in all sincerety, Who wants to pay taxes? You? Me? Who? (Well, actually theres this really weird guy I know who does, but I live in the Lower East Side - so go figure?) How much disposable income do you have? Will a daily four dollar "toll" be welcome? Let's see, I make 30K, (before taxes) so if I commute 300 times a year, that's $1200. An extra one or two percent on the sales tax? Hmm? Looking at my local tax bill, State and City, I see that they want to DOUBLE my tax bill... Now the proposed hike on the tax to the wealthy will STILL be less than the previous tax rates. A dramatic two percent rise. I'm shocked! quote: How New York State income tax rates are structured The tax table below will show in detail the New York state income tax rates by income tax bracket(s). There are 7 income tax brackets for New York. If your income range is between $0 and $8,000, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 4%. If your income range is between $8,001 and $11,000, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 4.5%. If your income range is between $11,001 and $13,000, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 5.25%. If your income range is between $13,001 and $20,000, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 5.9%. If your income range is between $20,001 and $100,000, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 6.85%. If your income range is between $100,001 and $500,000, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 7.375%. If your income range is $500,001 and over, your tax rate on every dollar of income earned is 7.7%. Notice how the wealthy pay sooooooo much greater a percentage than I do? Almost (but not quite) two entire percentage points... I must be Very Wealthy! Dave Interesting perspective and I thank you for it ... and the detail you provided. I guess the wealthier among you have one option that others don't have either ... they can afford to move (if they can sell their house). .....however the socialist system being pushed on us should be paid for by everyone...everyone needs to "buy" into the idea and do so by paying their share or it is domed to a class war... Already past the future

content: quote: Originally posted by peter3_1: The problem with NY is that they are gigantic waste of funds machines. An overpass on the BQE was under Const in the 1980's thru the 1990's. Asingle span over a surface roasway. Over a decade to complete. In the same period on Rt-13 down the Delmarva Peninsula, across the Chesapeak Bay Bridge thru VA Beach and south were completely repaved, an overpass built a bridge built, and 22 miles of 2 lane causeway on the Chesapeak Bay completed. Hmmm, a 50 ' overpass in NY, over 80 miles of roadway, an overpass,a bridge, 22 miles of causeway in VA, Same time frame....NY needs more money,,,why? I'm thinking CURRUPTION. i'M tired of supporting curruption. I'm opposed to throwing more money at people who sabotaged the Shoreham Nuclear power plant. The unelected Gov. shows no sign of being interested in reforming the curruption, only in collecting more tax. MORE, since I was a child, there has been an effort to get a real, COMPLETE financial statment out of the MTA .Where does all that toll money, subway and bus fairs , and other fees and emoluments go? They never say exactly. So, before we give them still more money, let's have a real accounting. How can these people mention fare share tax reform, without first looking at the abuse of the budget? They should be protesting for budgetary reform. The same people that cooked the MTA's budget....are still there. When ridership increased 40%..where did the money go? When Bloomberg increased property taxes, where did the money go? The MTA is crying poverty and threatening fare hikes and service cuts. This is all while cooking the books, and abusing taxpayer money. If they want to be fiscally irresponsible on the taxpayers dime, maybe it needs to come to an end. If they threatened to privatize the MTA, I do think you would start seeing the surpluses. "A clear message should be sent. If you can not manage your budget, and keep abusing taxpayer money, then we will find more competent people to run the MTA." Instead of funding the MTA through taxpayer money, which has been abused for way too long, there would be tax revenue generated, and the burden of the taxpayer funding the operation would be eliminated. It would free up more money for the city, and generate new revenue through the taxes collected. New York and Atlantic Railway could be a contender for the LIRR and subway lines. There are a host of other companies like Norfolk southern, UNP, and others that can also step in. SUNLINER, thank you for bringing up cap and trade. That will affect 100% of taxpayers. Don't forget the GWPRA, and carbon taxes they are proposing on top of the Cap and Trade Scam. When the CE Queens plant was converted to coal, the resulting cost savings in the first 8 days of operation covered the cost of the conversion, and, if allowed to continue to operate would have slashed New Yorkers energy bills tremendously. The conversion included a host of environmental controls, and brand new high efficiency EP's by way of Wheelabrator. I was watching the news one day and they were talking about investigating companies to find out why NY pays such high energy costs, while other states pay half of what NY pays per KW hr. They shouldn't waste the money with these investigations, and studies. All they have to do is look at the cost savings the Queens plant would have brought to NY. It isn't difficult to figure out.
